editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

note.p: Verse translations, by Thomas Newman, of Terence's Andria and Eunuchus.
The Eunuch begins on verso of F2 [i.e. E2].
Pages 50-51 repeated in number only; 60-61 and 63-64 missing in number only; 56-57 misnumbered 58-59; E2 missigned F2.
Errata on recto of H8, final leaf.
Preliminary pages and 81-82 torn. Beginning-page 1 and 76-101 from Folger Shakespeare Library copy spliced at end.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

div.head: The argument.
div.p:
A citizen of Athens dwelling at Sunium a port-town of Attica having two children, Chremes a son, and Pamphila a daughter, had his daughter stolen away by pirates when she was of such tender age that she could only tell her own and parents names. After this the Athenian died. The pirates sold the child to a merchant of Rhodes, who gave her to a strumpet which he loved. This harlot had a daughter called Thais, somewhat elder than Pamphila: which children she so brought up together, that all men of Rhodes did repute them for sisters. Thais in process of time took to her mother's trade of life; and yielding up herself to a stranger's devotion, was by him carried to Athens; where he dying left her good means. He thus dead, she was taken up by one Thraso a soldier: he also having a while accompanied her, had occasion of travail into Caria. Meanwhile
the mother of Thais died at Rhodes: her goods fell to a brother, who (With them) exposed to sale the abovenamed Pamphila, just upon the time wherein the soldier passed that way. Her youth and beauty induced the soldier (Ignorant of all passages) to buy her, as a fit gift to bestow on Thais at his return to Athens. But she before that time (Whores do not live in expectation, nor upon the means of one man only) had entertained the love of one Phaedria a young gentleman, son of an ancient Athenian citizen. She also had by this time gained some inkling of the parentage of Pamphila, and that one Chremes a gentleman of Athens was in good likelihood natural brother to the maiden: for better discovery whereof, she had had conference with him (A loof off) touching the matter. The soldier returns to Athens bringing Pamphila along with him, (Her maidenhead is questioned by Terence, act. 1. Scen. 2. in these words etiamne amplius? To avoid matter unfitting for the grace of the comedy, but she was (Beyond any contrary supposable conjecture) a maiden: for a child might villip this soldier out of his courage; and foolery was all the allurement he could use to her) and being thus returned, he finds Phaedria entered into Thais her books: out of which if he be not clean wiped, Pamphila is not for her, as the soldier affirmeth. Terence hath set out this Thais as none of the
worst of that course of life; and withal of good discretion in her carriage. A dilemma is now put upon her; love and consideration are the two horns: she must venture the goring by one of them. Love pleads first, and this is natural to her blood; and Phaedria besides deserves it. I but he may be tendered a wife; his appetite cloyed his father work her displeasure. Resolute love in spite of these premises hath down the conclusion on the other side a reputed sister, that sister hath good friends, those friends able to strengthen her unsettled fortunes; if by her means the one be restored to the other: thus pleads consideration. Wisely therefore she keeps the middle way for barring Phaedria her company for a brace of days (Telling him why) she aims to gull the soldier of the wench by this courtesy; and then to recall Phaedria to his former contentment. Phaedria assents, leaves the city. gives withal charge to Parmeno his father's man, for bringing an eunuch to Thais in his absence: Phaedria gone, Thraso also sends Pamphila to her by Gnato a parasite. In the passing of the maiden thither, Chaerea a younger brother of Phaedria spies her, falls in love with her, dogs her, by accident loseth her, chafes with himself at it: then to Parmeno coming upon him, discovers his mind and whereto carried. Parmeno informs him of an eunuch by his brother Phaedria sent, and by him forthwith to be conveyed
to the very house where the maid abideth. So that by shifting clothes with the eunuch he may undiscovered be brought to her; the eunuch nor he having ever before been seen by Thais or any of her family Chaerea follows the advice, is brought thither, ravisheth the maiden. Much coil hence ariseth, Pamphila at length being found to be freeborn, Chaerea marries her; Thais is taken into protection by the father of the two brothers. The soldier for mirth and cost sparing is admitted among them, by Gnato's persuasion, with the consent of Phaedria.

div.head: The actors and their characters.
div.p: Senex, an old man not named by Terence; father of two sons: himself being retired to his country grange, at his return to the city finds that either of his sons have played rex in his absence: his nature sudden and fiery.
Phaedria one of his sons, a young man entangled with the love of a harlot: well qualified and straggling with his faulty inclination.

Chaerea. Another of the old man's sons, an early cock of the game: the heat of his youthful blood violently caries him on to a rape: either he was passed an Ephebus, or grammarians mistaken in the word, or else Terence hath been very bold in the part of Chaerea lustful, heady, headstrong.
Parmeno, servant of the family, wise and discreet while he gives advice; when he undertakes employment diligent and faithful.
Thais, a strumpet of a sweet and pleasing disposition: graceful in language, in manners free and indifferently modest. Terence (In a word) hath strived in her person to set out a tolerable harlot.
Pythias maid to Thais. A busy prattling housewife.
Dorias another of her maids, of clean contrary temper: an idle meacock.
Chremes, a young country gentleman. Clownish of manners, very timorous and fearful.
Sophrona an old nurse, she hardly huddles over the stage: and all the news I hear from her, is this one word, moveo.
Amipho a young gentleman of good demeanour, familiar.

Thraso. Gnato. These I couple: for what good music makes a trumpet without its echo. The first a parrot, th'other a fellow clawing his poll. The soldier a bragging sot, of necessity therefore a cowherd; the other a clawback rubbing his proud itch. The parasite thus far wise, that he can make use of his foolish master: for he picks matter of mirth and means out of him.
Sanga a cook, by consequence inclining to sauciness. Malepert.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: If there be any who their studies frame
To give good men contentment, displease none;
In their fair rank our poet files his name:
If any further hold opinion,
That harsh uncivil terms to procure shame
To any man, be here ungently sown;
Let him think so a god's name: but with all
He lets them know, whatever words do pass,
Do not on such as free invectives fall;
But forced replies of him first wronged was:
To utter the man's name not need I shall:
One, shrewdly tossed, lewdly glossed has
Many Greek comedies: and by that mean
In that tongue good, in Latin marred clean.
'Twas he who but erewhile presented you
Menander's Phas●●. to name it is enough:
But in the treasure, there you saw him show
Rare work , exceeding his rich stuff.
One man another for found gold did sue:
(Our orators are but a glimmering snuff
To this bright poets shining oratory.)
Now in that case judiciously he wrought
The parry at the bar, then defensory,
To plead first, for the gold inquestion brought;
Before the plaintiff urged his injury;
Or reason showed why he by action sought
Recovery of that gold: or how the same
Into the comb of his dead father came.
I wish him henceforth, he himself not flatter;
Or think (His plays being passed) he stands secure
This will be unsafe refuge for the matter
I have against him: which (I him assure)
Is kept in store: and (Cease he not to scatter
His tales abroad our scandal to procure;
As he begins; and leave to urge us on)
Yet hull 't shall be produced to public view.
This eunuch now a foot for action
Being by the aediles bought, he hard did sue.
To be at sight of the relation.
The overseers come, the actors drew
To the rehearsal. I beseech you now,
But hear, what he hath challenged and how,
My man baules out in roar, a pilferer
No poet hath now tendered you a play:
And yet in all the same, no one word neither
Of's own, for's money tendered. Why, I pray?
Why out of Navius, Plautus, (Choose you whether)
All is purloined that you shall hear today.
And going on, the envious point he plies;
That this is stale stuff in each author named:
That either of them in their comedies
The soldier and flatterer's part have framed:
And that both thence are hither brought he cries.
Which, if 't be such a fault as must be blamed;
Our author says disknowing led him on:
No purposed filching practice thought upon.
That this is so, may by you straight be tried:
Menander's flatterer hath a parasite,
Which Colax called is; there is beside
A braggart soldier: that he did indite
Those personages thence is not denied,
To fill his eunuch: but that he did witthe eunuch was never before produced in Latin.
That this had ever been the argument
Of Latin plays before he utterly
Denies. If this now be so insolent,
To assume the persons used formerly
By other poets; why is sufferance lent
To frame a servant running hastily?
To fashion harlots wanton? matrons chaste?
Soldiers to vaunt? parasites cramming fast?
Why of false children are drabs brought to bed?
Why the old master cheated by his slave?
Why are not love, hate, jealousy yet dead?
There is no sentence (To conclude) we have,
Which hath not formerly been uttered.
It is but reason therefore, if we crave
Notice be ta'en; and our course pardoned:
If what in precedent the ancients gave,
New poets modestly have followed.
Pray lend your favour, and attentive ear;
That you our eunuchs news may fully hear.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: What should I then resolve on rot to go?
Not now at least, being so kindly sent to?
Or rather this way bend, my settled course,
Not to endure these scornful tricks of whores?
She shut me out of doors; now sends for me.
Go? never I, should she sue earnestly.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sir, surely if you can do as you say,
'Twere your most worthy, your most manly way.
But if beginning, you so go not one,
And faintly bearing love's affliction,
When you're not sought to, when you are at square
Shall then come creeping to her; and declare
Your ardent love, whose flames you cannot bear;
You are gone: shall be her pipe to play upon,
When you are sound at her devotion.
And therefore master timely yet consider,
That such a thing as holdeth in it neither
Reason, nor measure; such unruly thing
Cannot be brought to reasons governing.
In love these vicious humours settled are;
Suspicious, wrongs, enmities, truces, war,
New league again: now this uncertainty
To draw to certain, were like mystery,
As if one should a project venture on
To make a man mad with discretion.
And what you now here to yourself in passion
Do utter, shall I brook this base quean's fashion?
Who hugs you'd soldier? bars her door on me?
Not caring? I'll die first: she it shall see
What manner man she has to do withal.
These your high words, these hot terms tragical
With one false tear shall allay easily;
Which (Rubbing of her eyes most pitifully)
She hardly shall force from 'em: and anon
You'll tender your own accusation,
And stoop to her set penance.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: O my hard fate!
I clearly find myself unfortunate;
And her a wicked strumpet. I do fry
In flames of love to one I loathing fly:
Knowing and seeing fall; alive, awake:
Nor see my course.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: To what course should you take,
But seek to gain your liberty now lost,
At what low rate you may? if little cost
Will not procure it, then at th'utmost price;
And do not vex yourself.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: If you be wise, and to love's misery
Add not: what 'thas, strive to bear moderately.
But she comes forth; our households known decay.
For what we ought to have, she sweeps away.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Woes me, I fear Phaedria hath ta'en it hard
And worse than I did mean it, he was barred
His entrance here last day.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: O Parmeno,
How I do shake and shudder every part
At sight of her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I pray sir take good heart.
Approach that fire, you'll be warmed thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Who's that? o, were you my Phaedria so nigh?
Why stayed you here? why entered not straight way?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: But never a word of's shutting out last day.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Yes indeed I confess
Your house is still ope to my free access:
And I the favourite.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Why no more of it? O, o, Thais, Thais,
I would our loves were like; that this might thee
Equally trouble, as it troubles me;
Or that I could not weigh thy injury.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: I prithee sweet heart Phaedria do not grieve
Troth 'twas not that I love any alive
More than thyself, I did it: but the case
(As things fell out) so to be carried was.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Why, I believe her; as things came about,
The poor kind soul for mere love shut him out.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Say you so Parmeno? Leave that: and hear
Wherefore I now sent for you.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: But pray say first, can this your man keep counsel?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Who, I? exceeding well. But hear you Thais?
I pass my word to you, with this proviso,
All truth I hear I hold in exlently:
If lie, or toy, or fable, out it goes:
I'm full of chinks then, I leak everywhere :
If therefore you'll have counsel kept, speak truth.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: My mother born at Samos, dwelled at Rhodes.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: There a merchant
Bestowed a little girl upon my mother,
Stolen hence from Athens.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: I think so; do not know the certainty.
Herself did tell father and mother's name;
Country or other signs to be known by.
She knew not; nor indeed was't possible
By reason of her tender age she should.
The merchant thus much added, that he heard
The pirates say of whom he bought the child,
That it was brought from Sunium. My mother
Having received it, bred it, taught it so
In every thing, as if't had been her own:
And indeed most reputed her my sister.
Long after I left Rhodes, in company
Of a then stranger, whom alone I kept to,
And hither came. That stranger dying, gave
All the now goods unto me, which I have.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Either of these is false, 'twill out.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Because that neither were you satisfied
With him alone, nor yet had all from him:
Good and great part of it, my master brought you.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: I grant thee but permit me to go on
Whither I aim. Since that, a soldier
Who had begun to love me, travailed
To Caria: after which I grew into
Acquaintance with yourself. And you well know.
That I since then have held you inwardly:
Made you my bosoms only secretary.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: Neither will this be hushed by Parmeno.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: O do you make a doubt on't?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Pray attend.
My mother there at Rhodes deceased late;
Her covetous brother, heir to her estate,
Nothing the wench was fair, and skilled well
In music; hoped her at good rate to sell:
So forth he brought her, sold her to my friend
Who then there was; and fully did intend
To give the maid to me: yet nothing knew
Of all the passage I have told to you.
He coming home, and understanding too,
That in my love you likewise have to do,
He frames excuses to keep back the maid.
For (Says he to me) could he get belief
That he in my account should be held chief,
And you put by? or stood he not afraid
I having got her from him, presently
Would then forsake him; he would give her me?
But this he doubts. Yet I do rather guess
He fancies her.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: Has he yet done no more?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: No surely: for myself have (Phaedria)
Upon that point sisted her narrowly.
For many reasons I desire to get her;
First for she's deemed my sister: then beside
That to her friends I may the maid deliver.
Myself do hear a lovely woman bide,
Having nor kinsmen here nor yet fast friend;
Wherefore I seek to win some Phaedria,
By this good turn, I to the wench intend.
For my more ready working, I do pray
Thy help dear heart. The manner of my plot
Is, by your free consent for some few days
He may enjoy my love. Answer you not?

sp.speaker: Phae
sp.l: O woman wickedest of all thy race!
Should I reply ought to thy filthy doings?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O our brave young master! I commend him.
He's vexed at length: now sir you are a man.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: The issue of the tale I could not find:
Small girl stolen hence; my mammy as her own
Bred it; deemd sister; have a childing mind
To hea't; and to put it where 'tis known.
Whereto doth this your tale now wheel about?
But that thou lov'st me less than yonder lout,
And jealous art thy sweet pigsney does toute
On her, thee of his greasy grace cast out?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: What else troubles thee?
Is he alone a giver? didst e'er see
My bounty slight or slack? when late you said
You had a great mind to an Aethiop maid;
Did not I, laying all else care aside,
Cast out for one? and eunuch too beside
Thou wishedst; cause great ladies have
Such creatures; I found one; yesterday gave
Twenty pounds for 'em. Now despised by thee,
I yet retain this in my memory:
For these my kindnesses thou slights me.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Why speak you Phaedria in this angry manner?
Though I desire her, and think may obtain her
Best this way: rather yet then have a foe
Of you, I'll do as you will have me do.

sp.speaker: Phae
sp.l: Would that word truly from thy heart were brought;
Rather then me thy foe if I but thought
That this was spoke without dissembling,
I could myself frame to bear any thing.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: How quickly one poor word hath tamed him?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Do I poor soul speak it dissemblingly?
What thing did you ere crave though reastingly
At my hand, but you had it? I of you
Cannot obtain leave for a day or two.

sp.speaker: Phae
sp.p: If only two, and that if they prove not twenty.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: 'Tshall be no more: pray yield this liberty.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: Well: Thais I must do as you will have me.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: 'Tis well done
I'll to the country, and there pine a lone
For these two tedious days: I am resolved so.
Thais must be obeyed. You Parmeno
See those brought hither straight.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Thais
Farewell for two days.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: And you Phaedria.
Command you all else?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: What else should I say
With this same soldier present absent be:
Days nights thy love, fix thy desire on me:
Thy longings, dreams, thy hopes, delights, and mind,.
Fix upon me: be all with me: in fine
Be thy soul mine, as mine is truly thine.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Woes me; perhaps he hardly credits me,
But judgeth me by other wantoness trade:
But I that best know my own privity,
Know I have now no kind of leazing made:
And that I love, no man more heartily
Than Phaedria here: and that what I have said
Or done, is only for to help the maid:
I hope I have well nigh discovered
Who is her brother: a young man well bred.
He promised to visit me this day.
I'll get me in, and for his coming stay:

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: As I late bade, see those be hither brought.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Is this sufficient?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Good God ▪ what need you ask so?
Would you could find some good commodity,
As easily as all this will be lost.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Myself, to myself dearer, am lost too.
Do not so thwartly entertain the charge.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: No: but will see it done. Would you ought else?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Grace this my present with what words thou canst
And what thou canst, disgrace my rival from her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I had thought o'that, though you had not
Mentioned it.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: I'll to the country, and there keep.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Dost judge I may fettle
There to abide without returning back,
For all the time of my enjoined penance?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You? troth I think not: either I imagine
You'll pace again back to her presently;
Or want of sleep ith' ith'night will force you hither,

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: I'll work to weariness, that I may force sleep.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Put this into your task you'll watch weary.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: A way fool, thou talkest idly Parmeno:
I sure must weed this my effeminate mind;
Myself lovercoker. Can I not
(If need should be) for bear her company,
Yea, for three days together.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Wonderful!
For three whole days? advise sir what you do.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O you good gracious gods!
What disease call you this? is it not strange
That none should know him the same thing to be,
That erst he was? who late more stayed than he?
More temperate? less vain? but who comes here?
sp.stage: Enter Gnato with Pamphila, and a waiting wends.
sp.l: How! troth us the soldier's parasite
Gnato; who with him brings the maid along.
As present unto Thais. O rare sight!
Sweet countenance! 'tis mar'le but I shall have
Course entertainment of her here today
With my decrepit eunuch. Why her face
Puts down the mistress; Thais self doth pass.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: O you immortal gods! how far one man
Outstrips another? and what difference is
Twixt men of brain, and fools? this argument
Comes to my mind on this occasion.
Today I met one, of my rank and place;
No niggard pinchgut: but one, took delight
To havoc out his state in dainty morsels.
I note him rugged, nasty, drooping grown;
Beset with rags and age. Why how now fellow,
Say I to him, what does this dressing mean?
Marry, says he, poor creature having lost
All I enjoyed, see to what state I am driven?
Acquaintance, friends, all do abandon me.
Here I began (Measuring my own estate)
To hold him in contempt; and school him thus:
What, idle drone, hast thou so framed thy course
That no hope's left thee? hast thou sent thy wits
After thy wealth? dost not observe me
One of thine own rank and condition?
What clothing, colour, neatness,, plight of body
Have I? have every thing though nothing have:
And naught possessing, yet do nothing want.
I but (Sighs out my fellow) I poor caitiff
Cannot endure to be a jesting stock,
Nor suffer stripes for money. What, I prithee
(Reply I) should be gotten that way, thinkst?
Thou art clean wide: in former times, of old,
Such kind of fellows, shifted out a living:
This a new way of birding found by me.
There are a sort of men that fain would show
To have rare parts; and yet are nothing so.
I follow these; to these myself apply;
Not to make them sport by my foolery,
But my own sport of them I smile on these,
Withal admire their wits: whate'er they please
To say I do commend it: if straight way
They do the very selfsame thing unsay,
I praise that too: ought say they, ought deny?
The same I say, deny for company.
In fine, I on myself impose this law:
Their humours at all hands to soothe and claw:
And this is now found the most thriving way.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Troth a fine fellow: he of fool's mints madmen.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: While thus we talk, we reach to th' market place:
The joyful victlers haste to meet me there;
Fishmongers, butchers, saulsagemakers, cooks,
And fishermen: people to whom I had been
Both beneficial, while my state stood good;
And since 'twas sunk: and still advantage them.
These me salute, invite me home to dine:
Do welcome me. The hunger-starved fellow
I named, seeing the account men made of me,
And that I fared so well, so easily;
Humbly besought me he might learn the trade.
I bade him follow that if 't may be wrought,
Lake as professed philosophers have sought
To keep their names up in their sectaries,
According to their doctrines qualities:
Epicures, cynics, Stoics, Platonickes:
So these my followers be styled Gnatonickes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Do you not note what ease and trusting to
Other men's roast, may work a man to do?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Yet why thus loiter I, and not convey
This maid to Thais; and her further prey
To come to supper? but see Parmeno
The soldier's rival's servant, at her door.
He's melancholy: all's well. Sure the folk here
Are frosty witted: I am now determined.
To play upon the fool.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: By this their gift
They think that Thais now is their own cocksure.

sp.speaker: Gnat.
sp.l: Gnato does greet his chief friend Parmeno.
With wishes of much health. What dost man?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: I see't, but seest ought hear does trouble thee?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: I do believe it; but ought else?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: No, be not. But what thinks thou of this maid?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Thus you now mean, that we are cashiered hence,
'Las, all things suffer intercourse of change.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Parm'no: for these six whole months together.
I'll set thee at rest from trudging up and down
Or watching today break: make I thee happy?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I do commend you for it.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: I detain you:
Perhaps you were to go some whither else.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Then I pray a little
Lend me your furtherance: work my entrance here.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Well sir go on. Your passage now lies fair
By reason of this maid you bring with you.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Would ye have any called to you out of th' house?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Let but two days be passed over once;
And you that have the happy readiness
With your least singer now to open the doors,
I'll make you many a time hereafter knock
And kick your heels against 'em to no purpose

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: What do you still attend here Parmeno?
Pray, are you placed there sentinel, to watch
Lest any private messenger should run
Between the soldier and Thais hither.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Conceitedly! but indeed they must be
Things extraordinary, that may pleaseEnter Chaerea.
The soldier. But my masters younger son
I spy a coming hither: I do marvel
What 'tis hath drawn him out of the pyreum:
For there at this time he is public custos.
'Tis not for nothing. And he comes in haste:
And (Why God knows) his eyes about does cast.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: I am undone she's nowhere to be seen:
And I that lost sight of her am lost too.
Where may I search? where hunt? whom ask? what way
Take? I have no direction; but I have this hope left
Where ere she be, she cannot be long hid.
Beautiful face! hence forward I do blot
Out of the table of my fantasy
All other women: and do fall to loathe
These common beauties.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Mark this younker too?
I know not what he talks to himself of love.
O my most unfortunate old master!
Why this is such a hotspur, if he take
To wenching once, you'll think his brother's course
Mere tricks and gambads in comparison
Of what his furious rage will venture on.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: O all you gods and goddesses confound
That same old dotard stayed me on my way.
Lee them plague me too, that did deign to stay:
And further would not slight him. But behold
Here's Parmeno: well met.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Why are you sad?
Or about what so earnest? whither going?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Troth I not know, nor whither, nor bout what;
I am so utterly beside myself.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Now Parmeno make proof, what dwells in thee.
Thou knowest thou oftentimes hast promised me,
Bidding me think of something I desired;
And thou wouldst show how thou couldst pleasure me.
And this thou offeredst, when I secretly
Brought to the seller all our victuals to thee.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Now on my part 'tis found
What I desire: let me thy promise find.
Besides it is an action of that value,
Whereon thou mayst spend thy best sweat and labour.
This wench is nothing like our city mammets,
Whom their mothers strive to make low shouldered;
And lace hard in, to make 'em appear slender;
If any grow a little fleshlier
She's termed a champion; straightway dieted:
That be they of natural temper ere so good,
They tanner 'em to form of reeds or rushes:
And therefore they are made much on.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: Colour her own plump body; full of mettle.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Procure her me by force stealth, or entreaty;
I weigh not which way, so I may ento, her.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: That was chafing with myself
Trust now as I came hither: neither think
There's any living on, to whom good haps
Offering well at first, do end more thwartly.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Ask thou? knowest thou not.
My father's kinsman, Archidemides?
A man much of his years?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Whilst I
Follow the maiden, he comes just upon me.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Nay verily
Unluckily. The word unseasonable
Fits other chances better Parmeno.
I may swear safe, this six or seven months
Last passed, I ne'er happened to see the man;
But now when least I would, or had less need.
Seems it not strange, how thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: As distant as he was he huddled to me,
Bow-bent, palsey-handed, blabber-lipped, cough-strangled:
Ho, ho, stay, Chaerea (Says he) Chaerea stay;
Chaerea to thee I speak: knows thou my errand?
What is it, say I to him? marry — marry —
And half an hour after grunties to me
I have a trial to be heard tomorrow —
And what of that, say I? he answers me
See that thou tell thy father carefully,
That he remember to be early ready
To plead my cause. This our dialogism
Took up an hour of time, I asked what else?
No more sares he. I left him; looking backward
To spy the maid, she ith' mean time had turned
Down this way to our street.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: 'Tis ten to one
But he means her, that was now brought to Thais.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: When I come hither, she's not to be seen.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Did any company attend the wench?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: Yes, a parasite and a maid servant.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: 'Tis she cast of your care: all now is quiet.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Nay, but mind the business now in hand:

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: Say dost know her? or sawest her?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Saw, know her, know where she is?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: O my sweet Parmeno knowest her?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Here, brought to the harlot Thais,
And given her for a gift.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Who is so potent
To give such gifts?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Thraso the soldier,
Your brother Phaedria's rival.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Thou declarest
But a hard case my brother stands in then.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: You'd say so indeed, if you had seen the present which he provides to send in counterpoise.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: What, that drivel,
That filthy fellow he brought yesterday?
The old man-woman?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: He'll be coited out of doors with's present.
But I ne'er knew, this Thais was our neighbour

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: I'm a fellow of nothing.
Strange, I should ne'er have seen her? but dost hear?
Is she so fair, as she's reported for?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: But not to be compared to mine?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: I prithee Parmeno
Work that I may obtain her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I'll see to't:
I'll study for your furtherance and help. Command you me ought else?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Home; to convey those servants unto Thais.
As late your brother charged me.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: O blessed eunuch!
Who is to be there placed in that house.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Wherein, demandest thou?
That ever has so fair a fellow servant
To look on; talk to: under the same roof
Be still with her; sometimes take meals with her?
Sometimes sleep nigh her?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What if now yourself
May be made happy?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Say. Take's clothes

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: His clothes? what thence will follow?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I'll lead y' in is stead.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You may then enjoy
The benefits, which now you said he should;
Be present, eat, touch, play, and lie close by her:
Seeing 〈…〉 'em do know you, what you are.
Beside your face and years are such, you may
Pass easily for an eunuch.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Excellent.
I never in my life heard better counsel.
Let's in; and help to dress me presently.
Lead me, carry me, with all speed thou canst.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What meanest? troth I but reasted.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I have cast myself away.
What have I done wretch? whither thrust you me?
Will you now force me? Sir I warn you stay.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Foresee, if th'course be not too hot for us.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: 'Tis not I warrant thee, let's on.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ay, but
This bean will sure be threshed on my shoulders.
O 'tis a heinous practice we attempt.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: A hamous fig: is that a heinous practice,
If I be brought in a bawdy house,
And there return their own upon these gibbets
And plagues of men? which always hold om youth
In such contempt, and always work our torment?
If I do now put a like trick upon 'em,
As we by them are still gulled? or else rather
Is't fit, we still take their wrongs patiently?
I say 'tis fit I put the jest upon her.
Who'll blame me that shall hear on't? every man
Will say, I fitted 'em a pennyworth

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What means all this? If you be so resolved
You may go on. But pray you sir hereafter
Lay not the fault on me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I'll ne'er (Decline then) your authority.
Follow.

sp.speaker: Chae
sp.p: The powers divine prosper our course.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Did Thais (Sayest thou) give me such great thanks?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Not so much for the gifts worth, as that it came from you: that's her heart's pride sir.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I come forth to see
How time serves for conveyance of my present.
But lo the soldier.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: My kind destiny
Sure of a child bestowed this gift upon me,
That all I do becomes most acceptable.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: The King himself
Still used to give me singular great thanks
For all I did; to other men not so.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: The man that hath brain in him doth derive
Oft times the glory earned by others sweat
Upon himself: a thing that's rife in you.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Therefore the King still wore you —

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: True: gave the oversight
Of all his forces, all his plots to me.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Then, if weariness at any time
Of men, or tediousness of business
Possessed him; when he minded to be private,
Would — as it were — thou feelst me?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Yes when he would
Unload his mind — as 'twere — of care.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Yes, than
He would retire with me alone to banquet.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: O strange! you do describe a rare choice King.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Ay, he's a man of very few men's stamp.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Rather of none's if he converse with you.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: All men envied me; closely snapped at me;
I thus regard 'em; all (I say) bore me ill:
But one most deadly, whom the King had made
O'erseer of his Indian elephants.
He at a time being over saucy with me,
What said I to him, take you boldness Strato,
Because you have command over the beasts?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: So help me God, an exc'llent witty jest:
O singular! this was a wipe unto him.
Ah! and what he?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Your faith good gods! desperate fellow, caitiff,
Churchrobber.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I but what thinkst thou Gnato.
Of that same jest, wherewith I girded once
A youth of Rhodes being at dinner with me?
Did I ne'er tell't thee?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Never: I pray tell it.
I have heard it told above a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: This Rhodian I speak of, a raw young stripling
Sat once at banquet with me: when by chance
I had my harlot with me: this green novice
Began to speak broad: how now impudence,
Say I to him, art thou thyself hare-haunched
And huntest for venison.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Conceited, clearly, smooth, not to be mended
For God's love was't your jest? I thought it old.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Oft, abroad it bears the bell
For a prime witty one.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Alas,
Rash headless youth.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: For god's sake what did he?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Blasted. All there
Were ready every man to burst with laughter:
And in conclusion all 'gan now fear me.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: But dost hear wert
Best I cleared myself to Thais, of this maid:
For that she stands in jealousy I love her?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: At no hand: rather strive to increase her doubt.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Ask you? find you not, if any time
She do commend or mention Phaedria,
How it does vex you?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: To prevent that
This is your only remedy. When she
Names Phaedria to you, do you presently
Name Pamphila: if she at any time
Say, let us have home Phaedria to banquet,
Reply you, call in Pamphila to sing:
In fine, give like for like, to nettle her

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Ay, if she loved me, this might further Gnato.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Sing she expects and loves what you do give her,
She long since loveth you; you have long since
Easily got the start how you may grieve her.
She'll always stand in awe, lest any time
Upon offence ta'en you'll bestow elsewhere
That benefit, she now does reap from you

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: 'Tis right thou sayest. Strange, 't came not to my mind?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: That is a jest indeed; because you bent not
Your mind out or else Thraso what rare strain
Had it produced, if minted in your brain.
sp.stage: Enter Thais and Pythias her maid, with other wenches attending.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Methought , I e'en now heard the soldier's tongue
See where he is: Thraso my friend, well met.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: O my dear Thais, my delight, how dost thou?
Do you a little love me for your minstrel?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What a sweet proper handsel has he given her
At the first onset.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Then let's to supper. Why here stay you?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Mark tother Wiseacre too. A man may judge
He was of a man's getting.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: When you please,
I am in readiness.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I'll go towards 'em,
And make as if I now but new came forth.
Are you to go forth any whither Thais?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O Parmeno, well done: yes indeed today.
I am to go abroad.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Seest thou not
The man there?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Yes, withal his presence irks me.
Those presents from my master Phaedria
Are ready when you please.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What stay we for?
Why yet not hence?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Pray sir grant truce a while,
I may surrender up some trifling presents, I also may
Imparle and treat with her.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Some goodly present
Sure: nothing like mine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The matter self will
Show that. Ho there, bid those two I gave in charge,
Come quickly forth. Enter Blackemore wench and eunuch.
Come you here forward. This same wench was brought
From Aethiopia.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Where are you Dorus.
Come you hither. Here is an eunuch for you: mark
How sweet faced, of what a blooming age.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Now
As God help me a handsome youth.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What say
You to him Gnato? What fault findest thou? or what
Objects thou Thraso? hushed both: sufficient
Commendation. Prove him in learning, song or
Wrestling: such knowledge fitteth free-horn youth to
Have, I'll make it clear appear he's perfect in.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: For need, unwarmed with wine I could that eunuch

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And he that sends you these, does not require
That you should only live to pleasure him;
For his sake, bar all else your company;
Nor brags his battles, nor shows forth his scars;
Nor stands betwixt you and your benefit
As one does, I could name: but at such times
When he may be injurious to none,
Yourself disposed, and time convenient;
If then admitted, he rests satisfied.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: This shows he serves some poor and forlorn master.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: For no man sure that could procure another
Would endure this.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sirrah., hold thou thy peace,
Whom I do judge under all names of baseness:
For thou that framest thyself to claw that thing,
I thinkst mayest feed on fire.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: I'll have but in these first; and leave some charge
Among my servants, what I would have done;
And come out to you straight.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.stage: Exit Thais with the eunuch and blackmore
sp.l: Gnato do you stay for her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ay, for it fits not
A general walk with's mistress in the streets.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What should I use a many words to thee?
Thou art much like thy master.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: That which now you said,
And the other jest broke on the Rhodian
Came to my mind: but Thais is come forth.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Run you before and get at home all ready.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: You Pythias have a special care,
If Chremes chance to call here, you entreat him
To stay; if that he cannot fitly do,
That he would come again some other time:
If neither that he can, bring him to me.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: But what, what was it else
I was about to say? O, have a care
Unto the maiden, see you? and keep home.
sp.stage: Exit Pytheas into her mistress's house.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.stage: Exeunt Thraso, Thais and her train.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: The more I do revolve things in my mind
Still the more likely arguments, find
That Thais here aims some shrewd trick against me;
I see she works on me so cunningly.
When first she sent for me (If any one
Should then have asked me the occasion
Of business twixt us twain, I knew nothing
To answer) being come, with hammerit
She fashioned out pretences of my stay,
She had performed religious rites that day
Unto the gods, and would communicate
A weighty secret to me: (I then straight
Grew jealous, all this was some cunning strain,
She fits down by me; cause of talk doth frame
I seeming cold, her speech to this point came,
How long 'twas since my parents had been dead
Long since I told her: than she questioned
If I had land at Sunium? and how far
It lay from sea? this (I think) liketh her:
She hopes to work it from me. at the last
She drew to this, if I had no young sister
From that place stolen a many years now past?
Who then was with her at the time we missed her?
What things she had about her? or if any
Could know her? why should she these questions move
Unless (As is the impudence of many)
She fain herself would that my sister prove,
Of old so young hence lost? should she survive,
Her years at most reach not above sixteen;
Thais is elder than myself, I ween.
She craved me again come to her: let her drive
The matter, and her business to some head;
Or leave this sending: I'll not be troubled,
To listen her third errand. Ho, within —
sp.stage: Enter Pythias to her misteresses door.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I still affirm, I am laid for to be caught.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Thais did earnestly request you would
Return tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Then remain here
A while till she come back.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: If such be your determination,
I pray step over to her where she is.

sp.speaker: Chre.
sp.p: I care not if I do.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Darias go straight
And leadeth is gentleman to his soldiers.
sp.stage: Pythias returns into her mistress's house. Dorias enters and go away with Chremes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Some youths of us agreed on yesterday
A feast in common amongst us 〈◊〉 Chaerea
We made our steward, rings were given, time, place
Set down; time's past, where it appointed was
Nothing is ready, he not to be seen,
I know not what to say out, what to ween.
Now all the rest have laid the task on me
To seek him; therefore now I'll first go see
If he be gotten home. But who is that
Comes out of Thais house? is't he or not?
sp.stage: Enter Char. in the eunuch's clothes!
sp.l: 'Tis he. What creature's he become? what means
This his attire? what evil bodes his staring?
I cannot enough wonder, or conjecture.
But whatsoe'er it be, I'll aloof stand;
And angle for the secret now in hand.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Is none about the doors? Not one. Does none
Come yet behind me neither? No not one.
May I not now at pleasure vent my joy?
O Jupiter! now truly is the time
I easily could brook to part with life:
Lest some ensuing wretchedness thereof
Should hap to sour my present happiness.
No curious inquisitor now meet me?
That up and down would haunt me, weary me,
Kill me with tedious questions, why I skip thus?
Why am so jocund? Whither I am going?
Or whence do come? in what place got these clothes?
What is my aim? whether I'm mad or sober?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll to him, and obtain the thanks of him
He so desires to part with. Chaerea,
Why in such rapture man! whence this attire?
Why art so pleasant? or what aim'st thou at?
Art in thy wits? Why starest thou so upon me?
Why speak'st not?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: O happy day? O friend well met.
There's no man living, I would rather see
At this time than thyself.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I prithee, say
What is the matter!

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Nay truly I pray thee
Give me the hearing. Know'st thou not her here
My brother is in love withal?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes Thais:
As I do guess.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: A certain maid was given her today.
What need I blazon or set out to thee
This maidens matchless beauty, Anripho?
Thou knowest me choice in such deciphering.
She did inflame my heart.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Thou'lt say
She from the whole sex bears the bell away,
If ever thou shalt see her. What need words?
I 'gan to love her: by good chance there was
At home an eunuch which my brother had
Bought for this Thais, not then sent to her.
Here our man Parmeno an odd inkling gave me
Of a device, which quickly I laid hold on.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: If you would silent keep, you would
Know sooner.
First to change clothes with him, then cause myself
To be conveyed for him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What advantage should you win thereby?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Makest then a question? I should see, should hear,
Should be with her I loved, Antipho.
Was it a slight cause, or a trifling reason?
I was brought to her; when she had received me
She gladly led me home: commits the maid —

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: She chargeth me that no man come to her;
Commands me further, I not start from her;
But that alone I keep with her alone,
In a close chamber: I say, yes forsooth;
Upon the ground looking demurely.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: I am to go now forth (Says she) to banquet,
And with her leads along her maiden servants;
(A few young novice wenches left behind
To attend upon the maid) these presently
Prepare for her to bath. I wish them haste
While they make things in readiness, the maid
Sits in a closet, looking on a table:
Wherein was painted, how that Jupiter
Once rained in Danae's lap a golden showy.
I looked upon the piece too: and because
He had in former times played the like pranked,
My spirits were the more encouraged:
In that a God had taken human shape,
And in gold dew dropping himself through tiles
Had closely, finely, wantoned with his leman
And which of th'gods had done't? matie the same
Who shakes with thunder heavens high arched frame
Should I wormling (Then) make scruple of it?
I did not, but embraced it willingly.
When this I cast in mind, the maid meanwhile
Is called for in, to wash: goes, baths, returns;
And afterwards they lay her in her bed:
I waiting stand if they'd bid me do ought.
One comes to me, and says, you sirrah Dorus
Take you this fan; and thus fan wind upon her:
When we have washed, you (If you will) wash too.
I take it with sad countenance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: At that time
I would ha' seen that bashful face of thine
How thou great ass didst stand holding a fan

sp.speaker: Chae
sp.l: She had scarce spoken it, when all together
Hurrying out of the room, depart to bath;
And make such noise, as servants commonly
Are gone to do, when masters are from home
Meanwhile a slumber seizes on the maid.
I privily (Thus) on the fans side do leer,
And look about too, if all else be clear:
I saw all safe, and hoited fast the door.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Should I let slip such opportunity,
So proffered, short, wished and not hoped for?
I had been then indeed such as I showed for.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis true thou sayest. But in the meanwhile what's done
Concerning our repast?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou art careful: where? at your house?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: No at discus
Our freeman's.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis far hence, let's make more haste
Go shift your clothes.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Where should I go to shift?
I'm lost; from whom I stand as banished;
I doubt my brother may be now within:
Fear also, lest my father be returned
Out of the country.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Go we to our house,
That's the next place, where you may shift yourself.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: The advice is good, let's go: withal I mind
To take thy counsel, how I may my love
Further enjoy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: So help me God, I somewhat doubt poor creature
By things I saw, lest the enraged soldier
Should raise some broil; and do my mistress wrong.
For presently as soon as Chremes came
The late given young maid's brother; she requests
The soldier, he would cause him be called in:
He grew in sum, but yet durst not deny her.
She further moves his invitation
Unto their banquet: (This my mistress did
To keep him there; because as yet the time
Served not to tell him things concerned his sister.
The soldier willed him sit; yet grumblingly.
He placed, my mistress frames discourse to him:
The soldier thought a rival had been brought
Under his nose, and minding to cry quittance
Called out, ho, one of you fetch Pamphila
To sing to us; Thais cries out, at no hand:
What her to a banquet? He would have it so.
Hence grew the matter to a down right brawl:
My mistress privily took of her jewels,
And gave 'em me in secret to bring thence.
This is a certain sign, whereby I know
She'll slip thence, when she spies fit time thereto

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: As I upon my journey passing was,
A thronging troop of busy thoughts do press
Into my mind; as ought it comes to pass
To men whose souls some trouble seized has:
And every thing in the worse sense I guess.
What need much talk? while these dumps me possess
Unheeded I was passed the town I meant to,
And was gone far beyond it; when at last
Perceiving it I back returned fast:
And being scarce come unto the turn which went to
The town, there stayed; and in my mind thus cast,
Two whole days must I this place be pent to
Alone without her? Why is that such a matter?
'Tis nothing: nothing? What, if not come at her
To touch her? must I yet be barred her sight?
If that be crossed, is this to be lost quite?
To climb the lowest, first step of love's lather
Were somewhat yet. But why in such affright
Comes Pythias forth? and why so hastily?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Wretch that I am, where shall I find this fellow?
Where this ungodly wicked fellow find?
That he should dare attempt a piece of work
So monstrous, so audacious!

sp.speaker: Phae
sp.l: I am lost,
And doubt what this may mean.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Besides, yet further
The villain not alone defiled the maid;
But rent the poor soul's linen, tore her hair.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Whom if I now could light upon,
How I would fly upon th'eyes of th' witch?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: I cannot guess what coil hath here befallen
Since my departure. I'll go to her. How now?
What is the matter? why such haste? Who is it
Pythias, thou lookest for thus.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: O Phaedria,
Whom seek I? Sir I pray you get you hence
Where you deserve, with your conceited presents.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Ask you? what fine eunuch
Was that you sent? what stir hath he here made us?
H'has ravished the young maid, the soldier
Bestowed upon my mistress.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: I would
To God that all that hate me, were as drunk as I am.
Dorias. For god's love Pythias what strange hap was this?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: Thou'rt mad. How could an eunuch do such things?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: I know not what he was, but what h'has done
The case itself doth show. The wench she weeps.
And when one asks her, dare not utter why.
The honest fellow too's not to be found.
Beside I fear, he's run away with somewhat.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: You make me wonder, where the lazy bones
Should have conveyed himself: unless perhaps
He be retired back to our house again.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Pray, see if he be there.

sp.speaker: Dorias.
sp.l: I am to seek, good God sweet Pythias
I have not heard so strange and accident.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Yes, I had heard that they loved woman
Dear, but could do nothing. And forgetful beast
I never thought on't: else I had mewed him up,
And ne'er ha' trusted her unto his keeping.

div.head: Scen. 4.
div.stage: Enter Phaedria haling out of doors Dorus the eunuch in Chaereas apparel.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Come out o'doores mischievous rogue; come out.
What draw you backward? come forth runaway
Ill purchased commodity come forth.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Mark how the hangman
Wries his chops a'toneside? sirrah, what's the scope
Of this your coming back? the mystery
Of this your changing clothes? your answer sirrah?
If I had stayed never so little Pithias,
I had not found him there: he had prepared
Ready for packing.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Where is he?
Phae askest?
Seest him not?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: He that this day was brought you.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: None of us
E'er saw this fellow, till now Phadria.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: For god's love. (Phaedria) did you
Think,
That this was brought.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: Yes for I had no other.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Fie, there's between 'em no comparison.
That was a fair and comely visaged youth.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: You thought so then cause he had other clothes on:
Those off, you think him now ill favoured.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Au! pray sir cease: as if the difference.
Were small between 'em? here today was brought
(Phaedria) a youth you would ha' longed to look on:
This an old, creeping, dreaming, dropsy, dotard;
Complexioned like a weasel.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: How, how this?
Chrochets? you make me scarce know what I do.
Sirrah come near me did not I buy you?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Put forth your question.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Cam'st thou here today?
You see he does deny it: but the other
Came to us, hither brought by Parmeno,
Some sixteen years of age.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Resolve me this;
First, by what means got you the clothes you wear?
Silent? monster of men, speakst not? Dorus. Chaerea
Came home.

sp.speaker: Phae
sp.l: And
Who was with him?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: Hadst thou ever before seen him?

sp.speaker: Dorus.
sp.p: No, nor yet ere before had heard him named.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: How then didst know him to have been my brother
Dorus. Parmeno said so. He gave me these clothes.

sp.speaker: Dorus.
sp.l: Himself withal straight put on
Mine.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: You think me now not drunk; nor that I have lied.
'Tis now most clear the poor wench is deflowered.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: What need I
Believe him?
The matter self proclaims it.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Sirrah you,
Come hither (Here you) yet a little nearer:
So, 'tis well. Tell me again, did Chaerea
Take your clothes.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: And was brought for you to Thais?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: Great Jupiter! o wicked shameless fellow

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Woes me; you scarce believe yet we are abused.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: 'Tis mar'le now, but thou credit's what he says?
I'm at my wit's end — sirrah dost thou hear?
(Deny't being asked again) can I no way
Work a truth from thee? ha? didst see my brother?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: No truth, I see, unforced
Can be got from him. Come, come in with me.
Now say things straight deny 'em? (Beg of me.)

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Will you get in? Dorus
Hoy heigh.

sp.speaker: Phae
sp.l: I know no means else how to shift away.
I stand in a fair case, if such a knave
As thou, may thus befool me at his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: I know sure as I lief, 't was Parmeno.
Complotted this.

sp.speaker: Pyth
sp.l: Ere I sleep
I'll find a mean how to cry quittance with him.
But what thinkest best we should do, Dorias?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Yes, it't be best
To utter or conceal't. Dorias if you be wise,
Know ought, know naught, touching the eunuch self,
Or her abuse: so shall you keep from blame;
And do her a good turn. You may say only,
Dorus is run away.

sp.speaker: Dorus.
sp.l: But see I not Chremes vonder? Thais straight
Will be here with us.

sp.speaker: Dorias.
sp.p: Because when I came thence, they grew to brawl.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Bear in the jewels: I'll of him learn all.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Ay, ay, assure as heaven, I was but played on.
The wine o'er wrought me: yet while I was sitting
Methought I was exceedingly well tempered,
But rising found both feet and brains to sail

sp.speaker: Pyth. Chremes. Chr.
sp.l: Who's that? O Pythias how much
Fairer
Now seemst thou then erewhile.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: You in good sooth
Are pleasanter by fair.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: 'Tis true and old,
Spare wine and dainties, sportful lusts grows cold.
Is't long, since Thais came?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Hath she already
Then left the soldier?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: O yes long age.
And there has been great falling out between 'em.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Did she say nothing, you should follow her?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Nothing, but at her parting winked on me.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: What, was not that sufficient item man.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I knew not that the meant so much, but that
The soldier helped my dull conceiving her;
For out o'doores he thrust me: see where she is
I marvel where it was, I over went her.

sp.speaker: Thais
sp.l: I guess he will be here straight, with intent
To take her from me; let him come on then:
But if he lay on little singer on her,
I'll claw his eyes out. I can so far bear
His fopperies, and swollen bombasted words
Whilst that they be but words: come they to deeds once,
I'll ferret him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I was here long since Thais.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.l: O Chremes, I looked for you. Know you not
That all this brabble hath been about you?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Me? how? as if I broached it?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Yes because
While I do seek to render to your hands
Your long lost sister, this ensued thereon.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Why what's the matter? She has been
Brought up
As fits herself and you.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.l: That which is truth: freely give her you.
Demanding nothing at your hands for her.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I give and owe you Thais many thanks
As you have well deserved.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: But beware
Chremes, you lose her not, ere you receive her:
For this is she the soldier comes to get
By main force from me. Pythias get you in,
And fetch the little coffer with the tokens:

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Do you see him coming Thais?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Mistress
Where is it?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Ith' leathern hamper: mak'st thou no more haste quean?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What forces does he bring with him? o me.

sp.speaker: Chr
sp.l: A way, I afraid?
No man alive less.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: T'sh, I do doubt what man you take me for.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: No, but consider, he you are to deal with
Is a mere stranger, of less means, less known,
Less friended here then you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: All this I know:
But yet 'tis folly to admit an evil
Which may be well prevented. I had rather,
We seek aforehand to prevent a wrong,
Than to return a suffered injury.
Do you get in; and then make fast your doors;
Whilst I haste over to the market place.
I will have some assistants by, ith' tumult.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Pray leave.
I'll be here straight again.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Chremes this needs not,
Acquaint him only that she is your sister,
Which you a small girl lost; and now do know her:
Show him the proving tokens.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Here take 'em, if he offer violence,
Summon him to the law: conceive you me?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: See you utter it with courage.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Pull up your cloak there, to you.
I'm in a fair case: why, this man I make
My champion, needs another him to back.

div.head: Scen. 7.
div.stage: Enter Traso, Gnato, Sanga, with three others.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Brook such a base affront? I'll die first, Gnato.
Simatio, Donax, and Syriscus follow:
The house I'll first dismantle —

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.p: Take thence the maid my hostage —

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Donax come you here hither with your lever,
Into the heart of my battalion:
Simatio fall you there on the left wing.
Wheel you about Syriscus to the right.
Draw out some more: where's Sanga the centurion
With's band of the black guard.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Where are thy arms drone? wilt thou enter fight
With thy mop there? that thou hast brought it hither?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.l: Sir I but know the courage of my chieftain,
Or soldier's fury, that the day would cost
Much blood shed, brought it here to cleanse the gore.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: What (A murrain) rest?
Samnio alone keeps home, to look to th'house.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.p: Do you rank these; I'll march behind the van.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Note sirs his wisdom! having ranked the rest,
Himself retireth to safe place for shelter.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Thais, see you
What he intends? that sure's the safest way,
To lock up doors.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: This fellow (I assure thee)
Thou deemest a man of spirit is a gull;
A pure great goosecap: ne'er make doubt of him.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: I could wish you had
A sling stone here, to gall 'em a loose off:
They'd straight forsake their castle.

sp.speaker: Thra
sp.l: But I see
Thais herself.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Let's straight rush in upon them.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Forbear: a discreet general should cast
To win his aims by treaty, ere he put
The hazard unto battle. How dost know
But she may do my biddings, uncompelled?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: O you good gods! what 'tis to be distreeter
I ne'er come to you, but I do depart
Much bettered in my judgement.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Thais, first
Answer me this, when I bestowed on you,
The maid, assure you not your company
To me for certain days.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Askest thou what? that broughst before mine eyes
Thy lover? (What hast thou to do with him?)
And with him sneakest from me?

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Restore now therefore Pamphila, unless
You'll have me force her from you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: How, to thee
Restore her? or dar'st thou lay hands on her?
Thou? of all —

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Have care good sir, you know not
What kind of man you speak so grossly to.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Will you get hence? know you how stands your case?
If you disturb us here, I'll give you cause
To think upon this time, this place, and me:
Whilst you have day to live;

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: I pity you,
That seek to make so great a man your so.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'll crack your crown sir if you get not hence.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why what art thou?
What meanest?
What business hast thou with her?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Thou shalt know
First I affirm the maiden is free born.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: And my sister.
I therefore now forewarn thee soldier,
Thou use no force against her. Thais, he go
And fetch her nurse Sophrona hither straight;
And show her these remembrances.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Dost thou
Forewarn me that I should not touch my own?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I say I do forewarn thee.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Hear you sir,
You have good action of deceit against him.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: What's our course
Now Gnato?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Why let's retreat: she'll straight come after you,
Crouching and kneeling.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Nay
That's sure.
I am acquainted with these women's humours:
Sue, they are squeamish; if you keep off, they sue.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Shall I dismiss the
Army?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Sanga, as fits good soldiers,
Cast now your eyes back on the household chimneys

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: My mind was long ago among the platters

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.p: All follow me this way in.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Continuest drab to talk in riddles to me?
I know, I know not, heard so, he is gone,
I was not by —. Wilt thou not in plain terms
Tell me the matter? the maid's clothes are torn,
She weeps and silent keeps, the eunuch gone.
Why this? what's chanced? speakest not?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Woes me
Poor soul!
What should I say? they say he was no eunuch.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I have found it certain so.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Why what a god's name had he here to do?
Or why was hither brought?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: I cannot tell,
But that I guess he loved Pamphila.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: I find myself accursed wretch undone,
If this be true thou utterst. Is't for that,
The wench so weeps?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Thinkst so hegge?
Was this the charge I left you at my parting?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: What should I do? I left 'Him both alone
As you did bid.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Unlucky quean, thou left's
A lamb to the wolf: o I am ashamed,
sp.stage: Enter Chaerea in the eunuch's clothes.
sp.l: So to be played on. What man have we here?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Mistress, for god's love peace; we are well
We've caught
The man.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Look to your left hand.
Do you not see him?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Call out for help;
To lay hold on him with all speed you can.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: What shall's do with him fool?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: What do, d'ye ask?
Pray mark if when you wistly eye the fellow,
Has not a a shameless leer?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Note with what confidence my man struts too.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: As I but now to Antipho's did come,
His father and his mother were at home;
As if't had been so plotted so that in
I could not enter butt I must be seen.
Whilst here about the door a while I stay,
One that I knew came but into my way:
I him espying hastily betook
Me to my heels; and fled into a nook
Was unfrequented: so from place to place
Posted, till I to death nigh wearied was:
And this I did, lest any should me know.
But is not this Thais, I see? 'tis she:
I stick ith' mire; nor know I what to do.
But what care I? what dare she do to me?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Let's to him. O, you are well met honest Dorus.
Tell me, didst run away?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: And was it well done, thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Thinkst to go with't scot free so away?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Forgive me but this one fault, if I ever
Commit the like again, then kill me for't.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: I feared your maid here would tell tales of me.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Impudence
A trifle? is't a trifle in thine eye
To take a freeborn maid, and ravish her?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: I took her for my fellow servant.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Fellow?
I scarce can hold my singers from his ears.
Monster art come again, to flout us too?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Pray forsooth, why so?
I think I owed the gallows, if I do
As I do threaten; and the rather too,
Because he does confess he's slave to you.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: No more of this. Chaerea, you have committed
sp.l: An act fair unbeseeming that fair port
Yourself and friends here bear; say the scorn fitted
And to my course of life did justly sort:
Yet for your own worth you should have forborn.
Nor truly know I now what course to frame
Touching the maid; you have disordered so
All my proceedings, I cannot return
Her to her friends, as I desired the same;
And as was fitting for the maid to go:
So that both maid and friends I might have made
Beholding to me, by the course I laid.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Thais, but now I hope henceforth will grow
Fast love between us: oftentimes you know
From bad beginnings, slight occasion,
Great love hath had its derivation.
What, if some higher powers did thus decree?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: In such sense I do take it verily;
And so do wish't.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Pray one thing reckon right
No purposed scorn, but loves imperial might
Then swayed my passions.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: I believe 'twas so;
And truly therefore pardon you the rather:
I am not (Chaerea) of such stubborn nature,
Nor so unskilled as love's power not to know.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: So help me God as I now grow in love
With you to Thais.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Then mistress I perceive
You ought to watch him.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Introth le trust thee for just nothing.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Thais, I do commend, commit myself
To your protection; beg your help herein;
Desire, beseech you'll stand my patroness.
I cannot live if I not marry her.

sp.speaker: Chae
sp.l: Tsh, what? I know he will —
So she be known freeborn.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: If you please stay
A little, the maid's brother will be here;
He went to call the nurse that nursed her young:
You may be by at her acknowledging.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: And in the mean time will you.
(Till he do come) we go into my house?
'Tis better than at door here waiting stand.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Pray what d'ye mean to do?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: D'ye ask? mean you for all this yet
To let him come again into the house?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Take my word for't, he'll adventure
Some second battery.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Ha'you not had sufficient trial of him?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: I'll not trust you, Chaerea.
Unless you be kept out.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: But (Pythias)
Thyself shalt be my keeper

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Troth not I:
I'll neither trust thee with the custody
Of any thing, not keep thee yet myself.
So get you hence.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: I'm lost, pray let us in, I would not (Thais)
He see me in this habit in the street.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Yes truth? alack!
A maiden bachelor I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Go in before, I follow. Pythias
Tarry you here, to bring in Chremes with you.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: What, can I think of no plot, no device,
No trick to erie quittance with this rascal?
That foisted in this counterfeit among us?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: Pray move your joints a little nimbler ruise.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: Ay, I see't; but nothing forward.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Have you yet shown the tokens to her sir?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: What says she, pray? remembers them?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: In troth you bring good news,
For I do wish the maid well. Pray go in;
My mistress long since did expect your coming.
But see the honest fellow Parmeno,
I think I have found a trick to nettle him,
As I would wish. I'll first go in and hear
The maid's acknowledgement; and again come forth
To fright the rogue with a fine penny worth.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I now scout out, to see what Chaerea has done:
Who if he have the business cleanly handled,
Good gods! What glorious palm have I then won?
For to omit, that I a cafeintangled
Have wound out fairly to his hand; have wrought,
Have compassed his love, his wench, a maid
He so did dote on: and yet cost him naught,
(No purse expense, no trouble, hazard made;)
And from a greedy harlot. Then again
(Which I indeed account my master's prize)
That I have found him out a ready mean,
To learn these strumpet's manners and full guise:
Which ripely understood, he may for ever
Detest their courses: when abroad they get,
None are more neat and sweet in their behaviour,
They mince and pick upon each dainty bit;
(With their friend eating such is their demeanour.)
And then to note their greedy ravening,
Their sluttishness, their penury at home;
What nasty cormorants they are alone;
Out of stale porridge musty bread devouring:
These things are youths true cordials being known.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Rogue for thy deeds and words I'll plague thee so.
Thou shalt not for our wrongs hence scotfree go.
Your mercy o good gods 'O cruel practice!
Alas poor youth! but o that cursed villain!
That villain Parmeno, that brought him hither!

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: It pities me;
Therefore I hasted out of doors, poor woman:
Because I would not see't. O, what example
(Say thee) they do intend to make of him?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O God! what strange stir's this? am not I lost, trow?
I'll to her. What means this flight, Pythias?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Dost ask audacious fellow? whilst thou soughtst
To put a trick upon us, thou'st undone,
Hast utterly undone that pretty youth,
Thou broughtest us for an eunuch.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Dost know the maid was sent us is free born?
And has a brother here of great account?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: But she's proved so: this poor youth
Has ravished her; which when her brother heard of.
Coming in furious heat —

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Ay, although Thais begged the contrary.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: And now he further threatneth
To use him in such sort, as is the wont
To be performed upon adulterers.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Upon what confidence dare he venture
So heinous an attempt?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is't not the heinousest that can be thought on?
Whoever saw any one apprehended
For an adulterer in a bawdy house?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But that thou mayst know't
I tell thee (Pythias) 'tis my master's son.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Therefore let Thais look then,
She suffer him sustain no injury.
But why do I myself not receive him?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Parmeno consider what you go about.
Lest you not help him, and yet cast away
Yourself forever. For they do imagine
That all is done is of your practising.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What shall I do then wretch? or what contrive.
But lo, I see my old master newly come
Out o'the country: were I best acquaint him
What is befallen or not? I'll tell him, sure;
Though I do know, I shall pay soundly for it.
But I must do't, that he may help his son.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Ay, thou dost wisely. I'll go in. Deline.
Every thing to him, as it chanced in order.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: My country grange yields this commodity,
I find no irksomeness in field, or city:
I can shift place, being of either weary.
But is not yond our Parmeno? 'tis he.
Who wait you here for before Thais door?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Who's that's o Master 'You are welcome home.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I'm undone, my tongue
Falters for scare.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: How's this? why shak'st thou so?
Tell me, is all well here?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Master first I crave
You would conceive the matter as it stands:
That whatsoe'er hath happened, hath not come
Through any fault of mine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Indeed you urge the question orderly:
I should have first opened the cause to you.
Phaedria bought an eunuch to bestow
Upon her here

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Bought sayest thou? I am certainly undone.
What cost he?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Chaerea does love a minstrel wench here.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Ha! besides
What, loves sayest thou? does he already know
What a whore means? is he got to town too?
One mischief brood's another.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Pray you sir
Do not so eye me. This he does not do
Upon my setting on.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Sirtha, leave talk
Touching thyself. If I live (Pillory)
I'll but unfold first th' whole business to me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Chaerea was brought to Thais for that eunuch.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Yes sir, afterwards
They have taken him for an adulterer;
And bound him.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Pray note (Good sir) these strumpet's insolence.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Is there yet any further mischief left,
Or ill unuttered.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Why stay I
From breaking in upon 'em?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: There's no doubt
But I incur some famous punishment:
But since I must do't of necessity,
I joy yet I shall work these queans some mischief.
For th'old man long hath sought occasion
To plague 'em soundly: now at last has found one.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Trroth for this many aday there has not chanced
An accident more pleasant than this now;
To see the old man come in so mistaken:
'T was sport to me alone of all the rest,
Who knew the ground of th' error. ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: I'm come forth to
With Parmeno, but where a god's name is he?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: See where he is, I'll to him meet

sp.speaker: Par
sp.p: What news with thee now giglet?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What meanst thou? why this laughter? goest thou on?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, he. Oh-oh-i burst, I faint
With laughing at thee.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Dost thou ask?
Upon my troth I never in my life
Knew a more errand fool, nor ever shall.
Ha, ha, ha, he — it cannot be expressed
What pastime thou hast made us yond within:
And yet (Good truth) at first I took thee for
A very wise and cunning pated fellow.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: What at the first dash
Oughtst thou to credit every thing I said?
What didst thou think the brave exploit too little,
The rash youth ventured through thy setting on;
Unless thou further didst discover him
Unto his father? prithee, tell me one thing;
What thinkst thou Cherea thought, when now his father
Found him so fine dressed in an eunuch's habit?
How is't? seest thou yet, thou art ripe for hanging?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: How? what sayest thou pestilent quean, didst lie then?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And keepest a laughing still too?
Thinkst thou 'tis such fine pastime (Harlotry)
To make a scorn of me?

sp.speaker: Par
sp.p: Ay, if perchance thou carry't away, scotfree.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I'll cry quittance of my credit.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Yes sure. We shall have, time yet, Parmeno:
For thee, thou art to be trussed up presently;
Who fleshest heedless youth in villainy
And then betray'st him to discovery.
Father and son will both make thee an example.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Look you 'This you've got
For the eunuch you late ushered home to us.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Unlucky I am caught just like a rat,
Traced by my noise, mine own unheedy chart

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: What do we now? on what hopes? or with what purpose
Do we come hither? what intend you Traso?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Who, I to yield myself to Thais mercy,
Do all she shall enjoin.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why Hesse, than the valiant Hercules,
Who condescended to serve 〈◊〉?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: I like the precedent would I yet might see
Her crack your crown once with her pantofle.
What news? her door opens.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What new mischief's this?
I ne'er saw this man yet: what may it mean,
That he comes forth so hastily and jocund?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: O loving countrymen, lives any man
More happy than myself? troth, I think none
The gods have shown all their full might on me,
On whom so suddenly so many chances,
So many prosperous chances meet in one.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why is he grown so merry?

sp.speaker: Gnae.
sp.l: O my dearest,
